user_request: A poem for Valentine's Day about true love lasting forever.

revision_history.draft:
He ties his shoes and the laces stay
exactly where he puts them—
that's how I know. Not from anything said,
but from what happens when no one asks.

Every morning the coffee is already
the way I like it: too hot, then not.
The burned pot is on the back burner
when I finally notice the smell—

something charred and specific,
like a promise that had dried up
and been forgotten by whatever
was making it. He doesn't look up.

I watch his shoulders come off his shirt
at dinner, how the light catches
the exact same place each evening—
a small dent above the blade of his ribcage,

a crease he makes without thinking.
I could trace that with my thumb
and not know what I was measuring.

But here's the thing: neither of us says
*a pot burned itself.* We just eat,
silently, and the burning stays
inside its own small circle on the stove

like a bruise no one will see. Twenty years
of this—my coffee, his shoes
always crossed beneath the chair—
and then he sits back in his chair
and something has shifted
the way a river shifts
its channel when it finds
a softer bank.

I turn my head slightly.
He turns with it.

Now we are both looking at the window
where rain is not falling yet,
but the glass holds the exact
shape of where it would fall—how heavy
it must feel, how ordinary,
how much the house expects.

He doesn't say a word. I don't either.
We sit like this for several seconds
the way you hold still when you hear
a bird outside and neither of you
has ever heard it before—

then the window is just a window again,
ordinary as the laces on his shoes.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The final four lines earn everything the poem has been building toward:

> We sit like this for several seconds / the way you hold still when you hear / a bird outside and neither of you / has ever heard it before—

This is the poem's real engine — not because of the idea, but because it trusts silence. The comparison to holding still for a sound achieves something precise: it makes stillness *felt* through anticipation rather than explanation.

> then the window is just a window again,

The deflation is devastating. The metaphor collapses back into literalness with genuine force. This is where the poem's argument lives — that what seemed extraordinary was never anything but glass doing its job.

> ordinary as the laces on his shoes.

That final parallel closes the whole arc in three words. It doesn't need to say "I love you." The laces have been crossed for twenty years; they're still crossed. That's the declaration.

The poem is strongest when it stays inside domestic objects and gestures — the burned pot, the ribcage dent, the way he crosses his ankles. These are specific, and they carry weight without needing to announce themselves.

---

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / Overexplaining (lines 1–4):**
> He ties his shoes and the laces stay
> exactly where he puts them—
> that's how I know. Not from anything said,
> but from what happens when no one asks.

The poem tells us it's going to be about unspoken love, then immediately *explains* its own theme. "That's how I know" is a narrator stepping in to narrate. Cut or radically compress — the action of laces staying put does the work already. Let the reader arrive at the insight without being told there is an insight.

**Abstraction creeping in (lines 13–16):**
> something charred and specific,
> like a promise that had dried up
> and been forgotten by whatever
> was making it.

The poem shifts into abstract metaphor — "promise," "dried up" — right when it should be staying with the physical object. The burned pot is *the* thing. Name or describe it. "Whatever was making it" is pure filler, a placeholder for something the poet hasn't yet found.

**Cliché:**
> how much the house expects.

This line reaches for profundity and lands on sentimentality. It tells us what the poem has already shown — that routine is expectation. Cut or replace with an image as concrete as "laces staying put."

**Weak transition (line 26):**
> Twenty years / of this—

The ellipsis before the list risks vagueness. Name one more object, one more gesture. The accumulation in lines 27–30 works; give it its full weight by

revision_history.draft:
He leaves the coffee maker's ring
on the back burner, dark
and cracked like a face that's been
frequently slapped. I don't mention it.

Tuesdays he folds the towels
the wrong way on purpose—dried creases,
each one pressed into the cotton
like a visa stamp—and I fold them right.
We keep folding.

At dinner his shoulders come off his shirt
again, that small dent above his ribs
exactly where the collar would find it,
and I could trace it with my thumb
but don't. The glass holds
the exact shape of rain.

He sits back in his chair and something shifts—
not dramatic, just the way a river settles
into a new edge. I turn my head slightly.

Now we are both looking at the window
where rain is not falling yet,
but the glass already clouds
like it has seen it coming.
How ordinary. How much the house expects it.

He crosses his shoes beneath the chair again.
I fold another towel right. He folds a stack of nothing—tapestries, really—
corners knocked so they never meet.

I watch him peel an orange at the counter,
the white pith curling off in one strip,
impressive even to me after all these years,

and when he holds it out I take half without looking.
The kitchen smells like Sunday again—the oil,
the fruit, his cologne from a decade
when he wore it every day and didn't notice.

He doesn't say the pot. I don't either.
We eat. The burned orange curls on the counter
curl exactly how oranges curl—
that's what they do, that's all.

His shoes stay crossed beneath the chair.
I fold another towel right.

final_poem:
He leaves the coffee maker's ring
on the back burner, dark
and cracked like a face that's been
frequently slapped. I don't mention it.

Tuesdays he folds the towels
the wrong way on purpose—dried creases,
each one pressed into the cotton
like a visa stamp—and I fold them right.
We keep folding.

At dinner his shoulders come off his shirt
again, that small dent above his ribs
exactly where the collar would find it,
and I could trace it with my thumb
but don't. The glass holds
the exact shape of rain.

He sits back in his chair and something shifts—
not dramatic, just the way a river settles
into a new edge. I turn my head slightly.

Now we are both looking at the window
where rain is not falling yet,
but the glass already clouds
like it has seen it coming.
How ordinary. How much the house expects it.

He crosses his shoes beneath the chair again.
I fold another towel right. He folds a stack of nothing—tapestries, really—
corners knocked so they never meet.

I watch him peel an orange at the counter,
the white pith curling off in one strip,
impressive even to me after all these years,

and when he holds it out I take half without looking.
The kitchen smells like Sunday again—the oil,
the fruit, his cologne from a decade
when he wore it every day and didn't notice.

He doesn't say the pot. I don't either.
We eat. The burned orange curls on the counter
curl exactly how oranges curl—
that's what they do, that's all.

His shoes stay crossed beneath the chair.
I fold another towel right.
